doc.name: TAN keywords for types of divisions
doc.desc: Definitive list of key terms used for textual divisions.

tan-vocabulary.name: TAN keywords for types of rights
TAN keywords for types of groups

item.name: does not start new line
no new line start
inline start
not nls
not(^\n)
item.desc: Text divisions that typically do not begin on a new line

item.name: no new line end
does not end new line
inline end
not nle
not(\n$)
item.desc: Text divisions whose termination does not force the next text division to start a new line

item.name: start new line
new line start
nls
^\n
item.desc: Text divisions that typically begin on a new line

item.name: new line end
end new line
nle
\n$
item.desc: Text divisions whose termination forces the next text division to start a new line

item.name: start extra leading
extra leading start
space above
item.desc: Text divisions that typically begin with extra leading (a horizontal line of white space)

item.name: end extra leading
extra leading end
space below
item.desc: Text divisions that typically end with extra leading (a horizontal line of white space)

item.name: start new column
new column start
ncs
item.desc: Text divisions that typically begin on a new column

item.name: new column end
end new column
nce
item.desc: Text divisions whose termination forces the next text division to start a new column

item.name: start new page
new page start
nps
item.desc: Text divisions that typically begin on a new page

item.name: new page end
end new page
npe
item.desc: Text divisions whose termination forces the next text division to start a new page

item.name: logical
conceptual
item.desc: Text division is based on logical units that do not depend upon scripta for their meaning, e.g., sentence, paragraph. Contrasts with physical, scriptum-based divisions.

item.name: scriptum
scriptum based
object
physical
material
item.desc: Text division is based on a physical feature in the scriptum, e.g., page, column, line. Contrasts with logical divisions.

tan-vocabulary.name: TAN keywords for types of rights
TAN keywords for types of roles

doc.name: Commonly used vocabulary in English for divs that are unnamed, first system
doc.desc: There are a handful of div types that do not easily lend themselves to values of @n because that type of div is traditionally not labeled or numbered. In practice, @n is given a value that is identical to, or looks a lot like, the value of @type. This TAN-voc file tries to provide a lingua franca for such unlabeled div types.

tan-vocabulary.name: TAN keywords for types of rights
TAN keywords for types of roles

to-do.comment: Need to test against real-life examples, to add other commonly unlabeled div types, and to massage the nomenclature.

doc.name: TAN keywords for features
doc.desc: This file contains in TAN-voc format the core vocabulare adopted by OLiA for parts of speech: http://purl.org/olia/olia.owl.

tan-vocabulary.name: TAN keywords for types of rights
TAN keywords for types of roles

group-type.name: perseus features
Perseus features
group-type.desc: Grammatical features that appear in Perseus's morphological analysis of Greek and Latin words that do not appear to be featured in OLiA's vocabulary.

attribute n

item.desc: The group contains items that define groups of division types

doc.name: TAN keywords for types of modals
doc.desc: This file has been created ad hoc to reflect the kind of modal qualifiers that textual scholars habitually employ to nuance their claims. These categories are not to be seen as necessarily correlating with any branch modal logic.

doc.name: TAN keywords for verbs
doc.desc: This file has been created ad hoc to some basic terms for verbs involved in the creation and editing of TAN files.

tan-vocabulary.name: TAN keywords for types of rights
TAN keywords for types of roles

group-type.name: verbs that have subjects that are text bearing objects: persons, agents, scripta, versions, works.
Verbs that have subjects that are text-bearing objects: persons, agents, scripta, versions, works.
verbs that have objects that are text bearing objects: persons, agents, scripta, versions, works.
Verbs that have objects that are text-bearing objects: persons, agents, scripta, versions, works.
verbs that have objects that are claims.
Verbs that have objects that are claims.
verbs that require objects
Verbs that require objects
verbs that may not take objects
Verbs that may not take objects
verbs that indicate a passage of text in each of the subject and object where there is agreement of 70% or greater.
Verbs that indicate a passage of text in each of the subject and object where there is agreement of 70% or greater.
group-type.desc: If subject and object are in the same language, the quantity is measured by agreement after normalization, ignoring accentuation, capitalization, punctuation, and word spaces. If they are in different languages, the quantity is measured by the number of words in one source that correspond to words in the other.

group-type.name: verbs that indicate a passage of text in each of the subject and object where there is agreement of 40% to 70%.
Verbs that indicate a passage of text in each of the subject and object where there is agreement of 40% to 70%.
verbs that indicate a passage of text in each of the subject and object where there is agreement of 5% to 40%.
Verbs that indicate a passage of text in each of the subject and object where there is agreement of 5% to 40%.
verbs that indicate comparisons between subject and object.
Verbs that indicate comparisons between subject and object.
verbs that establish symmetrical relationships between subject and object. if x [verb] y then y [verb] x.
Verbs that establish symmetrical relationships between subject and object. If X [verb] Y then Y [verb] X.
verbs that establish transitive relationships between subject and object. if x [verb] y and y [verb] z then x [verb] z.
Verbs that establish transitive relationships between subject and object. If X [verb] Y and Y [verb] Z then X [verb] Z.
verbs that require or or more <locus>.
Verbs that require or or more <locus>.
group-type.desc: These verbs are intended to support claims about how specific persons or scripta corroborate or depart from the reading of a particular locus of text.
